title: Who will the European Council appoint as the next European Central Bank (ECB) president?
possible_answers: No appointment will be made before 1 October 2019
correct_answer: No appointment will be made before 1 October 2019
preds: Too much turmoil to make an important decision due to brexit

On September 17, 2019, the European Parliament voted via secret ballot to recommend Ms. Lagarde to the position of ECB President, with 394 in favor, 206 opposed, and 49 abstentions. If confirmed by the European Council in its October summit, she will succeed Mario Draghi and would become the first woman to serve as ECB President.

Christine Lagarde is nominated for the post, but will not be fully appointed before 1 October.

Christine Lagarde (born in France) is the only nomination for the ECB presidency.
Mario Draghi's, the incumbent, tenure comes to an end 31 October 2019.
The procedure is that the formal appointment must be made by the European Council, which is only scheduled to meet 17 - 18 October 2019.

Following helpful links from @Deelou [1] and @Raisinville [2] and timeline  pulled together by @TeeL [3], Lagarde from France seems almost certain to be the next President of the ECB (> 95%).  However, the appointment will require a confirmation vote from the European Council, and their next meeting is not scheduled until 17-18 October, which is after the question's deadline.  Leaving a 1% chance that GJO judges interpret the "appointment" as having occurred even prior to the "confirmation" of her becoming EDB President on 1 November. It will be Lagarde, but not before 1/10/19.  What is needed for the nomination:
- ECON meeting of the European Parliament - should be feasible, they have several meetings in September, e.g. 4-5/9 and 12/9)
- Vote in EP plenary (doable, e.g. on 16 Sep.)
- Governing Council of the ECB (e.g. 12/9)
- European Council meeting - the next one is 17-18/10, which is too late considering the 1 Oct dead-line in the question So, assuming the schedules won't be changed, I don't believe that she will be nominated before 1 Oct.

I am forecaster #38 on GJO.  I remember a question like this which, ironically, also involved  Lagarde, the resolution of which has bearing on this question. See:  https://www.gjopen.com/questions/87-who-will-be-the-next-managing-director-of-the-imf The question was:  Who will be the next managing director of the IMF?
That question was closed prior to July 1st and scored retroactively to February 16th, before Lagarde actually began her second term as the managing director of the IMF on July 1st.   I am of the opinion that the resolution of that question should not have been retroactive,  since anything -- including Lagarde's death -- could have happened between February 16th and July 1st when the term began.  To the best of my knowledge, GJO Admins never responded to my challenge of the resolution of that question and the question has never been re-scored.   Fast forward to this question.   IF GJO IS TO BE CONSISTENT IN THEIR QUESTION RESOLUTION, THIS QUESTION SHOULD ALSO BE RETROACTIVELY RESOLVED. OR, GJO should acknowledge that an error was made when question #87 was closed retroactively,  and re-score it. @amory10, @Emil, @dsarin, @nigster

Christine Lagarde has just been nominated by EU leaders as the next president of the ECB. It is highly unlikely that this nomination will not be confirmed by the European parliament which is the next step. Erkki Liikanen of Finland and Jens Weidmann of Germany were other names that had been discussed as possibilities.

Didn’t see that coming!
“European leaders nominated Christine Lagarde, head of the International Monetary Fund, to become the next president of the European Central Bank. Her nomination must be formally approved before she takes over from Mario Draghi, whose term ends on October 31st. The leaders also nominated Ursula von der Leyen, Germany’s defence minister, to become president of the European Commission. “

Lagarde's nomination was announced in a tweet by European Council president Donald Tusk following a meeting between leaders that has lasted since Sunday. While her appointment still needs to be confirmed by the European Parliament—Tuesday's vote, from the heads of European states, is the first step—the nomination sets her up to be the first female head of European monetary policy.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/maggiemcgrath/2019/07/02/imf-head-christine-lagarde-nominated-to-run-the-european-central-bank/#44401b265826

And from the Economist this morning - no clarity yet and how this is tied into other appointments:
“This morning European Union leaders convene for a meeting that was never meant to take place. They had gathered in Brussels on Sunday to discuss the allocation of big jobs like the presidencies of the European Commission (the EU’s executive), the European Council (the collective heads of government), the European Parliament and the European Central Bank. Also in the mix was the role of High Representative for foreign affairs and security policy, a sort of EU foreign minister. Yet they could not reach a deal. A package by which Frans Timmermans, a Dutch social democrat, would become Commission president was backed by Angela Merkel and Emmanuel Macron but opposed by other leaders. Central European governments in particular objected to Mr Timmermans’s robust defence of liberal values. Today EU leaders will try to find a blend of candidates that tick all boxes. Mr Timmermans is not yet out of the running, but leaders are eyeing alternatives.“

From the Economist... Sounds like Holland inching closer to EU presidency. That means I have to bump up Deutsche leader of ECB.

Frans Timmermans, a vice-president of the European Commission, emerged as the frontrunner to become that body’s next president. To win, Mr Timmermans, a former Dutch foreign minister, will need the support of 72% of EU governments representing 65% of the EU’s population.”

Talouselämä reports on the EU haggling season, the naming of the new EU commission president* is timetabled for next weeks summit. Other positions included in the democratic negotiation process (Brexiteers included) are the i) ECB president (not subject to the political results of the EP elections, but part of the whole process), ii) High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy (Frederica Mogherini), iii) President of the EP (the parliament itself selects), iv) President of the European Council, and the v) (*Juncker). The challenge here appears to be that the power in the elections has moved to a broader base form the EPP and the social democrats that had the majority before 2019. What does this mean to the ECB president nomination? It means the big picture with the right balances to country (north/ south), party, gender (and suitability??) have to harmonise with the power scale. Other lesser pieces to the negotiations are the program of the commission, where parts of the program are influenced, and parts of the whole negotiation process. Noteworthy is that the main list of ECB president candidates does not include any women, but some names are in the mix (Claudia Buch, Lagarde). Hence I began to think Margrethe Vestager, therefore, has very good cards heading the commission going into next week. Barnier? FWIW - All prospects are still in the race. Timetable:
Nominations next week (appears to delay...)
Europarliament starts in July
Hearings of candidates by EP starts in September
New Commission should start November I drained the "No appointment will be made before 1 October 2019" bucket as there are no signs of stalling, blockage or other politic dark clouds hovering around. Black swans still lurking? Brexit? Very early in the game so much can (and will) happen. (1) https://www.talouselama.fi/uutiset/komission-puheenjohtaja-ekpn-paajohtaja-eu-korkea-edustaja-eun-huippupestien-taytto-alkaa-juhannuksena/c00a9a4e-e116-4d8a-964c-fc1f9f240708

Have been tracking this one closely to no avail. To many interdependencies with other EU roles and typical European compromise/horse trading. I think it’s down to Claudia Buch (De), Villeroy  (Fr), or Liikanen (Fi). Any guess between them is a guess dependent on other moving pieces.

- Jens Weidman (D) is a no-go. However, if Macron blocks Weber (Spitzenkandidat for EC president), the Germans might want to push someone to ECB (instead of having a top job in the Council or the EP), but they don't have much good candidates. 
- Erkki Liikanen is getting old and e.g. the Greeks (and other less strict economies in the Southern part of Europe) might oppose Olli Rehn (commissioner during the euro-crises...)

Finding the argument that the Germans might not want their guy in charge of the ECB because of problems it might create with Italy and passing a euro budget interesting and apparently, there is some horse trading with France to put their preferred candidate on the commission in exchange. So, things look like they are coming into place for Finland. According to a survey by Bloomberg, France and Finland are most likely to be the country of origin of the new to be appointed head of the ECB. Candidates from Germany come in third place (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-who-will-be-the-next-ecb-president/). 
Furthermore, the top candidates considering previous experience as well as likeability are coming from the countries mentioned above (https://www.politico.eu/article/the-perfect-ecb-president-should-be-olli-rehn-eu-finland-banking-eurozone/). 
http://bruegel.org/2019/05/the-next-ecb-president/

Talouselämä, The Economist journal of Finland, reveals a decision tree probability based on German intelligence information, where German-French balance is key (of course), and where Germany could decide the horse-trading seating carousel of EU presidents and ECB chair in a way that plays straight to Liikanen's bucket. The main point is that the commission presidency or the ECB chair occupied by Germany could unnecessarily strain the relations towards the south European countries and EU budget process issues, mainly Italy. So a compromise from the Hansa-pact Northern countries would be a given, and Liikanen is the number one horse in that scenario. This puzzle is anything but solved, starting with the commission presidency, Verstegen-Timmermans-Weber-Barnier-Merkel? This can go many ways. And Bloomberg has updated their article on the ECB chair: "There’s a New Favorite in the Race to Succeed ECB’s Mario Draghi". There the #1 Frenchman has the lead. Moving to a compromise solution. We kind of look like Japan and ECB is running out of ammunition. German option is suicidal but they (Germany) will not let France manage it.

From the Economist:
“Bank-watchers are accustomed to trying to anticipate the ECB’s monetary-policy actions. Though inflation has been disappointingly low, little is expected from the central bank’s meeting today, beyond the details of its new lending facility to banks. A bigger decision hangs over the institution this year, one that will be made by politicians not bankers: who will replace Mario Draghi as the ECB’s president? Leading contenders include the heads of the French and German central banks, the current and former governor of the Bank of Finland, and an insider already on the bank’s executive board. Politicians know their choice is an important one, given the ECB’s role in propping up the euro area’s economy. But with the job only one among several vacancies at the top of European institutions this year, there is plenty of scope for horse-trading too. This decision might defy prediction.“

Increasing looks like a standoff between France and Germany. "Finland’s Erkki Liikanen and Olli Rehn probably won’t be put forward in Brussels as their country has been governed by a caretaker administration since national polls last month...The two Finnish central bankers -- Rehn heads the national central bank and Liikanen is his predecessor -- may also lose a potential ally. Austria, which might have backed a compromise candidate for the ECB to avert a standoff between Germany and France, may be represented in Tuesday’s summit by a caretaker leader without a mandate to push for specific picks." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-05-27/election-hangover-may-delay-ecb-pick-as-leaders-turn-lame-ducks?srnd=economics-vp

This will depend in part on which country gets the position of European Commission president. With increasing support for Vestager, there is a higher likelihood that Germany will be able to claim the ECB seat. I am therefore increasing Germany's chances from 15%.

But she is less dominant than she used to be, and will probably not back Mr Weber at any cost; some think she is more interested in placing a hawk at the head of the ECB."  https://www.economist.com/charlemagnes-notebook/2019/05/28/why-margrethe-vestager-ticks-all-the-boxes
If someone from Brussels is a possibility then that’s my best guess.

Finland appears to be in slight lead...
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-05-06/race-to-replace-draghi-spurs-ecb-calls-for-fed-style-rethink

There are two people from Finland in the running, both of whom can be counted on to stay true to policies consistent with Germany's preferences.  Automatically this increases Finland's chances since they have double the number of candidates in play.  The current president of the Bundesbank is unlikely to want or receive the job.  The other contender from the Bundesbank has insufficient support in Europe.  Ireland is a dark horse and could be rewarded with this role as a means of strategically addressing Brexit policy issues.  While France's central bank governor is highly regarded, France is not currently viewed as a contender because France is targeting the presidency of the Commission as its preferred priority.  Germany is also pushing for a premier Commission position.  Policymakers will not want to have the ECB positioned as a consolation prize.

Update, this looks like a 3 horse race. But cows are going to get traded before this is settled... Updating previous forecast using Bloomberg's economist poll using the new numbers from May 7th[1,2]: France: Francois Villeroy de Galhau (49), Benoit Coeure (36), Christine Lagarde (1) = 86 / 199 = 43%
Finland: Erkki Liikanen (41), Olli Rehn (31) = 72 / 199 = 36%
Germany: Jens Weidmann (29), Klaus Regling (6) = 35 / 199 = 18%
Ireland: Philip Lane is the Economist, no one else in the running (0) = 0%
Someone else: Ardo Hansson (3), Klaas Knot (1), Pablo Hernandez de Cos (1), and Claudia Buch (1) = 6 /199 = 3% Total is 199.  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/822048
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-who-will-be-the-next-ecb-president/

Among 5 top candidates from Bloomberg survey among economists, updated in 2/2019, top 1 and 3 are Finlish, top 2 and 4 are French, 5 is a German (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-who-will-be-the-next-ecb-president/). This make the first three options are very likely.  France: Reuters reports sources to indicate that France will push for the presidency of the European Commission rather than the European Central Bank. Paris is eager to secure one of the most powerful jobs in the European Union, with the Commission seen as preferable because it has a greater role in shaping legislation at a critical juncture for the European project, whereas the ECB’s monetary policy responsibilities are narrower. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-election-france-commission/france-targeting-commission-presidency-over-top-ecb-job-sources-idUSKCN1R61T9) Germany: PIIE: "already the stars are lining up for a German to serve as the next president of the ECB, most likely Jens Weidmann, the president of Germany’s central bank, the Bundesbank." Despite Germany’s status as Europe’s biggest economy, no German has held the position of ECB president, the most powerful economic job in the region. It is now politically palatable to say “it’s Germany’s turn now”. (https://piie.com/blogs/realtime-economic-issues-watch/why-next-ecb-president-will-be-germany-and-probably-jens)

Finland: Olli Rehn and Erkki Liikanen both have a good chance and would be a good neutral choice for the bigger  / permanent members.
France: Francois Villeroy de Galhau has a chance, but considering the past presidents from the Netherlands, France, and Italy other nations will likley want a turn. Coeure is also mentioned in the press but, as a sitting board member, he is not eligible for reappointment.
Germany: Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann has antagonized many. He publicly opposed the ECB’s stimulus program, credited with reviving growth, and got into a public fight with Italy’s prime minister over fiscal discipline.
Ireland: Philip Lane, the main contender, will likely become Chief Economist.
Netherlands: Klaas Knot - same as above, Netherlands has had the president recently. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecb-policy-explainer/musical-chairs-ecb-prepares-to-reshuffle-board-idUSKCN1LQ1VV

Front Runners:
1. Erkki Liikanen, EU Veteran.  The 68-year-old stepped down from his post as Finland’s central-bank governor in July, and would bring decades of Brussels experience to the top of the ECB as governments try to solve the single currency’s structural shortcomings. ***
2.  Francois Villeroy de Galhau, German-Speaking Banker. France’s central-bank governor is considered a serious contender if governments balk at appointing a German. Since taking over at the Bank of France in 2015, Villeroy has stuck close to Draghi’s line backing continued stimulus. 
3. Jens Weidmann. Francophile Hawk. Weidmann became the Bundesbank’s youngest-ever president in 2011 after his predecessor resigned to protest ECB bond purchases. Now 50, he’s taken a hard line against loose monetary policy, earning him respect at home but criticism from Draghi for his perceived “nein zu allem”—no to everything—attitude. ***
4.  Olli Rehn, Finnish Eurocrat. Rehn, 56, may be one of the newer faces in European central banking, but he’s been involved in economic affairs for years. As EU commissioner in charge of the euro during the region’s debt crisis, he was a strong advocate of ﬁscal discipline before returning to Finnish politics in 2015 as economy minister and overseeing the country’s emergence from a three-year recession. ***
5.  Benoit Coeure, Markets Maestro. Coeure, 49, is already on the ECB's Executive Board with a non-renewable eight-year term that runs until the end of 2019. He's highly respected though, and it's possible a way could be found to shift him to the presidency. He's one of the architects behind quantitative easing and is responsible for markets, so he certainly has the necessary experience. 
6.  Klaas Knot, Dutch Hope. The 51-year-old head of the Dutch central bank is one of the youngest members on the Governing Council. He’s also typically on the same page as Weidmann on the topic of monetary stimulus, speaking out against keeping asset purchases going for too long. 
7.  Klaus Regling. The Underwriter. One of the architects of the euro, Regling spent a decade at the German Finance Ministry where he helped prepare for economic and monetary union. In his current position leading the European Stability Mechanism, a backstop for countries in financial crisis, the 68-year-old has had close insight into the euro area’s existential woes. 
8.  Christine Lagarde. Trailblazing Globetrotter. Lagarde made her name breaking tradition in a world of predominantly male economic policy makers. As French finance minister from 2007-2011, she was the first woman to hold such a post in a Group of 8 country, and since then has been the first female head of the International Monetary Fund. Lagarde would also be the first woman to head the ECB and the first president without an economics degree. 
________________________

With only 2 data points to use, the previous ECB Presidents were appointed around June/July of the year the outgoing President's term expired, so giving no appointment 0%. Using the same FT / Bloomberg polls everyone else cites, I set my base percentages for Finland, France, and Germany, then took the remaining points for Ireland and Someone Else, and added them to my base for Finland since all of the articles thus far seem to be favoring a Finn.

The Irish candidate has been named for chief economist and is liked by existing board members, and that puts him in the building: if they can't get agreement elsewhere, he's on the spot and already cleared to work there.  I still think is unlikely to be from France or Germany, and Italian and Spanish candidates would lack credibility.

Basing this on reporting from Bloomberg (link below) who has been surveying economists on their predictions for the next ECB president. They are reporting that Erkki Liikanen of Finland is the favorite followed by two Frenchmen. A German seems unlikely given Germany's existing economic dominance and the unease across much of southern Europe with the austerity policies pushed by most Germans. In the end the role will be appointed as part of a larger agreement divvying up the top jobs across the EU so it may be someone unexpected depending on who feels left out. https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-who-will-be-the-next-ecb-president/

An Irish economist is already getting a good position at the ECB, which makes another appointment unlikely. Irish central bank chief Philip Lane is the sole candidate to replace Peter Praet as the European Central Bank’s chief economist in May, virtually ensuring that a key ECB post will remain with a dovish policymaker. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eurozone-ecb/irelands-lane-sole-candidate-for-ecb-board-seat-idUSKCN1PO2BN?il=0 For president, Banque de France Governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau is seen as the favorite. Other candidates could include Jens Weidmann (Germany), Olli Rehn and Erkki Liikanen (both Finland), Klaas Knot (Netherlands) and Ardo Hansson (Estonia). Coeure (France) is also mentioned in the press but, as a sitting board member, he is not eligible for reappointment. Some have suggested that if he resigned before a nomination, he could gain eligibility, but such a move would be unprecedented and contrary to the spirit of the law. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecb-policy/explainer-ecb-reshuffle-kicks-into-high-gear-idUSKCN1PO2BB?il=0 An appointment is very likely by the due date. The next ECB president and the new heads of the European Commission and the European Council are all likely to be negotiated as part of a package after the European elections in late May. Draghi was appointed four months before he formally took over in 2011. The timeline will be tighter this year but the process should end by the time Europe shuts for summer holidays. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecb-policy/explainer-ecb-reshuffle-kicks-into-high-gear-idUSKCN1PO2BB?il=0

Tweaking France down because there was already a ECB president from France, in exchange tweaking Finnland up.

There'll be no appetite for a  German or France: untainted candidates would be in smaller countries, preferably ones with a reputation for discipline. There are some very bright people in Scandinavia and the Baltics, though maybe not current establishment in Denmark or Estonia (the DB inquiry) These would be from outside the Eurozone which itself could be an advantage.

Following a similar rationale as @cafebedouin excellent forecast from Bloomberg, but with some adjustments: An expected response would be who is best prepared to deal with the problems the Euro will face in the future, main ones being Italy, promoting structural reform and lack to resources for a new quantitative easing. However, national politics will prevail. Finland: member of the New Hanseatic League, the candidate could represent the north vs France and south division. However, one of the candidates is close to Draghi and the other one is a technocrat, and there is already a south (Spanish) vice-president. It could have Germany's support (porbably a de-facto New Hanseatic member). +5 points
France: Macron's position given the way he managed the gilet jaunes has weakened, and his party is not a member of a Euro parliament alliance, so less influence. However, see point about New Hanseatic League above, it could be their south representative. +5 points, excluding Lagarde as an option.
Germany: represents the opposition to the "whatever it takes", probably what Eurozone needs now but challenging for next crisis. Based on some comments that Germany is focused on the EC presidency (Merkel's legacy), it will not push for ECB. -10 points
Ireland: the only founding member not having a site in the ECB Executive Board (president, VP and 4 members), it could be an intermediate solution north-south (Ireland is a member of New Hanseatic League) and prepared for structural reform. +8 points.
The Netherlands: was not in the top four candidates, I adjust to 1%, same as other countries and no new president.

I'm going to go with the Bloomberg economist poll, updated December 21, 2018 as the base rate.[1]  Finland: Erkki Liikanen (39), Olli Rehn (21) or 60/196 = 30%
France: Francois Villeroy de Galhau (36), Benoit Coeure (30), Christine Lagarde (6) or 72/196 = 37%
Germany: Jens Weidmann (25), Klaus Regling (6) or 31/196 = 16%
Ireland: Philip Lane (18) or 18/196 = 9%
Someone else: Klaas Knot (13), Pablo Hernandez de Cos (2) = 15/196 = 8%
No appointment: I think we can safely discount Someone else down to 3% because Klaas Knot is from the Netherlands and they have had a previous president and Pablo Hernandez de Cos due to Spain's seat on the executive board. Christine Lagarde can be discounted because she is a lawyer and French. While France has the most contenders, I think the fact that there has already been a French ECB President plays against all of them as well, so discounting them down 17%. Adding a 2% hedge for no appointment, and voila! Methodology: "Respondents were asked to rank the three most likely candidates for the ECB president job when Draghi’s term expires on Oct. 31, 2019, with three points awarded for a top ranking, two points for second and one for third. Each individual result was then divided by the maximum vote possible and multiplied by 100 to come up with a final score. Twenty-four economists took part in the December 7-12 survey."  "Instead a Finn or a Frenchman (and it will be a man) will take charge, promising continuity in policy."[1] "The race is open and a surprise is possible,” said Mujtaba Rahman, managing director at Eurasia Group in London."[2] [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-who-will-be-the-next-ecb-president/
[2] https://worldin2019.economist.com/euroturns20
[3] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-01-08/draghi-will-be-passing-on-baton-with-ecb-in-populist-crosshairs
